attributes.title: The Gap Between Us: Income Inequality Reduces Social Affiliation in Dyadic Interactions
attributes.description: This project consists of two experiments examining the effects of income inequality between two individuals on social capital—defined in terms of affiliative intent and social warmth—in the context of a face-to-face interaction. Overall, we demonstrate that greater inequality produces more negative emotional responses, reduced desire to affiliate with one’s partner, harsher evaluations of one’s partner, and lower observer ratings of behavioral warmth.

q1.value: The Effects of Inequality and Inequity on Social Affiliation

q3.value:
In two previous experiments, we examined the effects of inequality and social power on several key indices of social affiliation using a semi-structured interaction between participant and confederate. In both studies, the two individuals were randomly assigned to a low- or high-power role and compensated either mildly or extremely unequally. Overall, we demonstrated that greater inequality produced more negative emotional responses, reduced desire for closeness with and harsher evaluations of one’s partner, and lower observer ratings of behavioral warmth.

However, it has recently been suggested that deleterious responses to inequality can potentially be attributed to, or moderated by, issues of inequity—the perceived fairness of the income distribution (Benedetti & Chen, 2018; Oishi et al., 2011; Starmans, Sheskin, & Bloom, 2017; You, 2012). To thus provide additional nuance to inequality’s effects on social affiliation, we aim to conduct a third experiment in which both inequality and inequity are orthogonally manipulated.

q4.value:
Based on the findings from the two previous experiments described above that inequality hampers social affiliation for those at the lower and upper ends of the income distribution, we hypothesize that we will replicate our significant main effect of inequality with this design. Those experiencing greater inequality should report more negative views of their partner and less affiliative intent than those experiencing less inequality independent of inequity condition.

Furthermore, based on prior work suggesting that the effect of inequality on redistributive behaviors can vary depending on how equitable the income distribution is perceived (e.g., Gee et al., 2017; Rustichini & Vostroknutov, 2015), our main effects may be qualified by a significant interactive effect of inequality and inequity. However, results from experimental work are conflicted as to how these two related factors interact. In one recent study, the authors found that increased inequality had less of an impact on wealth redistribution choices when income was equitable (i.e., earned through performance) than when income was inequitable (i.e., earned through luck; Gee, Migueis, & Parsa, 2017). In contrast, Rustichini and Vostroknutov (2015) found that, when outcomes were performance-based, low earners became more likely to subtract the winnings of higher earners at a cost to themselves, and did so in greater amounts, as the income gap increased, possibly due to negative feelings experienced in response to performing more poorly on the task. Inequality did not have the same impact when outcomes were luck-based. This suggests two possible interaction patterns: (1) greater inequality will reduce social affiliation in the high-inequity condition compared to the low-inequity condition (e.g., Gee et al., 2017), or (2) greater inequality will reduce social affiliation in the low-inequity condition compared to the high-inequity condition (e.g., Rustichini & Vostroknutov, 2015).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This experiment involves a 2 (inequality: high vs. low) X 2 (inequity: high vs. low) between-subjects factorial design. Participants will complete the experiment through the Software Platform for Human Interaction Experiments (SoPHIE; Hendriks, 2012), a platform in which experimenters are able to create web–based human interaction experiments. The experiment will be presented to participants as a study of “how social interaction styles relate to performance on financial decision-making tasks,” and that they will be completing an “investment task” as well as a short interaction task with a partner, ostensibly another MTurk worker. After providing consent, participants will be directed to a waiting room in which they will be matched with another actual MTurk user who happens to be taking the experiment at the same time (herein, “interaction partner”). Participants will be asked to exchange five messages with the interaction partner using a chat message system that they will ostensibly use during the experiment (McAuliffe, Forster, Philippe, & McCullough, 2018). No instructions for what to discuss will be included; the ostensible purpose of the chat is simply to familiarize the participants with the chat function.

After this brief introductory period, participants will complete an “Investment Task” modified from past research (Brown-Iannuzzi, Lundberg, Kay, & Payne, 2014). In the task, participants will make three investment decisions regarding how much out of $1,000 in seed money to invest between two companies. Paragraphs describing the companies, as well as information about each company’s past stock performance and price-earnings ratio, will be provided. After completing the task, participants will be told that 6 months of stock-market activity will be “simulated on the basis of real-world performance.”

In all conditions, participants are told that both they and their partner will be paid bonus compensation for participating in our study, but that the amount each individual will receive will differ. This payment will constitute our key experimental manipulations of inequality and inequity. In all conditions, they are told that the lower earner will receive a bonus of $2. In the low-inequality condition, they are told that the higher earner will earn $3, whereas in the high-inequality condition, they are told that the higher earner will earn $9. In reality, all participants will be told that they earned the lower amount and that their partner earned the higher amount.

In addition to a manipulation of the level of inequality between participants, this experiment will contain an orthogonal manipulation of inequity, or the perceived fairness of the income discrepancy (e.g., Connor, Stancato, Yildirim, Lee, & Chen, 2020). In the low-inequity condition, participants will be told that whether they receive the higher or lower bonus payment will be decided based on their performance in the investment task—if they perform better than their partner they will receive the payment, and vice versa. In the high-inequity condition, participants are told that the bonus compensation amounts will be decided based on chance—one of the two will be randomly assigned to receive the higher payment and the other will be randomly assigned to receive the lower payment (see Gee et al., 2017, for a similar procedure).

Upon completing the investment task, participants are told that they and their partners will be engaging in a short discussion. One of them will be randomly designated as the “writer,” who is to write for five minutes describing their ideal weekend in as much detail as possible, while the other person will be designated as the “reader,” who is to read and respond to what the “writer” wrote (McAuliffe et al., 2018). Although participants will be under the pretense that they are still communicating with their interaction partners from the pre-experiment chat, they will in fact be interacting with preprogrammed computer scripts at this point and are all assigned the “reader” role through a sham random process. They are again reminded that, after this task, they and their partner will complete another perceptual task. 

Participants will then receive the following “letter” from their interaction partner: “My ideal weekend would involve relaxing and productive time. On an ideal Saturday, I would wake up early in the morning and go to the gym for about an hour. I would try to convince my roommate to come along to the gym with me.  After a good workout, I would go home and take a shower. Then I would go to a café and study for the remainder of the afternoon. On Saturday night, I would relax with friends and watch movies on Netflix until late night. On Sunday, I would go straight to a café and study until I got hungry, then I would go home and eat some food. Then I would study some more and hang out with my roommates. Throughout my day, I would occasionally check Facebook and text with friends.”

After reading the letter, participants are asked to write a message with their thoughts and feelings about the letter to the writer. They will be told they need to write a minimum of 1-2 sentences, but are welcome to write more if they desire. After sending their response, participants will then complete our key dependent measures followed by two attention check items determining whether participants could recall how much they and their partner were paid and whether their partner did a perception task of the same or different difficulty level. They will then be informed that they will not complete another task with their partner and fully debriefed.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where participants will be randomly assigned to one of four cells in our 2 X 2 design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from Amazon's MTurk to complete the study. Participants will be paid $4 plus a $2 bonus for completing the entire study. Participants who attempt to participate in the study but are not paired with another MTurk worker after a seven-minute waiting period will be paid $0.75 for showing up but will not be eligible to complete the rest of the study. Participants who fail to correctly answer any of our attention check items will be excluded from final analyses.

Participants will also complete an open-ended suspicion probe in which they are asked if they believed that any information was withheld from them. Any participant who explicitly states that they did not believe either (a) that bonus payment was assigned on the basis of instructions corresponding to the two inequity conditions or (b) that they were participating with other real participants will also be excluded from analyses.

q13.value: We are aiming for a final sample of 520 participants for analyses. We aim to recruit a total of 570 participants to allow room for exclusions due to failed attention checks and suspicion.

q14.value: Our intended sample size was determined by a power analysis based on an effect size estimate (η2 = .015) from a previous study which manipulated inequality and fairness perceptions orthogonally (Benedetti & Chen, 2018). The results of this analysis suggested that we can achieve 80% statistical power to detect a significant interaction between our two factors with as few as 520 participants (130 per condition).

question.value:
Our study will utilize a 2 (inequality: high vs. low) × 2 (inequity: high vs. low) experimental design. In all conditions, participants are told that both they and their partner will be paid bonus compensation for participating in our study, but that the amount each individual will receive will differ. This payment will constitute our key experimental manipulations of inequality and inequity. In all conditions, they are told that the lower earner will receive a bonus of $2. In the low-inequality condition, they are told that the higher earner will earn $3, whereas in the high-inequality condition, they are told that the higher earner will earn $9. In reality, all participants will be told that they earned the lower amount and that their partner earned the higher amount.

In addition to a manipulation of the level of inequality between participants, this experiment will contain an orthogonal manipulation of inequity, or the perceived fairness of the income discrepancy (e.g., Connor, Stancato, Yildirim, Lee, & Chen, 2020). In the low-inequity condition, participants will be told that whether they receive the higher or lower bonus payment will be decided based on their performance in the investment task—if they perform better than their partner they will receive the payment, and vice versa. In the high-inequity condition, participants are told that they bonus compensation amounts will be decided based on chance—one of the two will be randomly assigned to receive the higher payment and the other will be randomly assigned to receive the lower payment (see Gee et al., 2017, for a similar procedure).

EMOTION MEASURES: Participants will report on their subjective emotional reactions using twelve items from the Modified Differential Emotions Scale (Fredrickson, Tugade, Waugh, & Larkin, 2003)---six positive emotions (hope, gratitude, contentment, interest, joy, and pride) and six negative emotions (anger, sadness, hate, envy, disgust, and contempt). Each item lists three words corresponding to a different emotion (e.g., “joyful, glad, or happy,” “angry, irritated, or annoyed”) and asks participants the extent to which they are currently experiencing each on a 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely) scale.

DESIRE FOR CLOSENESS WITH PARTNER: Participants will complete a five-item scale assessing their desire for closeness with their partner (van Kleef et al., 2008). Participants respond to each item using a 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) Likert scale. The five items are:

1. I would like to get to know my partner better.
2. I feel like my partner and I could be friends.
3. I feel close to my partner.
4. I would like to befriend my partner.
5. I would like to spend more time with my partner.

PARTNER TRAIT RATINGS: Using a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree), participants rated their partner on traits indicative of warmth (friendly, warm, likable), three of competence (intelligent, skilled, competent), and three of moral integrity (trustworthy, honest, sincere; Leach, Ellemers, & Barreto, 2007). 

INCLUSION OF OTHER IN THE SELF: Participants will be given the Inclusion of Other in the Self Scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992), a validated, one-item pictorial measure of psychological closeness. Participants will choose among seven pictures of increasingly overlapping circles the picture that best represented the connection that they felt with their interaction partner after reading the interaction partner’s letter.

RESPONSES TO THE LETTER. We will use a scale composed of three items to judge the affiliative intent of participants’ responses to their partner’s letter regarding their ideal weekend. Specifically, we will have two research assistants rate the extent to which the responses were positive, warm, and interested. These three items will be summed and averaged into a single index of affiliative intent. Reliability of coders’ judgments will be calculated using intraclass coefficients. Assuming the codes are reliable, we will average the two coders’ scores together to create a single affiliative intent score for each participant. Raters will be blind to our hypotheses, the conditions to which participants are assigned, and participants’ other data.

For our emotion ratings, positive and negative emotions will be aggregated into separate subscales for analyses (Fredrickson et al., 2003).

For our desire for closeness measure, all items will be aggregated into a single index.

For our trait rating measures, items assessing perceived warmth, competence, and trustworthiness will be aggregated into separate subscales.

Two-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) will be used to analyze the effects of inequality, inequity, and their interaction on all dependent variables. Simple effects analyses will be conducted in the event of significant interactions between our two factors to determine the effect of inequity within each inequality condition. Effect sizes for all results will be reported as well as confidence intervals for each effect size estimate.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and simple effects analyses suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: Participants who fail to correctly answer any of our attention check items will be excluded from final analyses. Furthermore, any participant who explicitly states that they did not believe either (a) that bonus payment was assigned on the basis of instructions corresponding to the two inequity conditions or (b) that they were participating with other real participants will also be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any item within each measure, that subject will not be included in the analysis for that measure.

attributes.title: What Makes a Classroom a Community? Teacher Mindsets and Student Sense of Belonging in Middle School Math Classes

q1.value: What Makes a Classroom a Community? Teacher Mindsets and Student Sense of Belonging in Middle School Math Classes

q3.value:
We propose to build on insights rooted in contemporary psychology to understand how the mindsets and practices of teachers influence students’ sense of belonging and academic identity in middle school in general and in middle school mathematics classes in particular. Despite a wealth of literature on the subject of belonging, it remains unclear how much student sense of belonging varies across organizational contexts, including schools and classrooms, nor the extent to which teacher behaviors and beliefs contribute to students’ sense of belonging. We ask the following research questions:

How is student sense of belonging distributed within and between middle schools? 

How is teacher mindset related to student sense of belonging, academic identity and student success in middle school in general and mathematics classes in particular? How if at all does the relationship vary by student race and ethnicity? 

What sorts of practices, behaviors and instructional environments are associated with stronger student sense of belonging and math identity for middle school students in general and students of color in particular?

q4.value:
We hypothesize that organizational contexts, teacher beliefs and teacher practices shape students’ sense of belonging and academic identity in ways that differ among students from different racial and ethnic groups. In general we expect to find that (1) student sense of belonging and academic identity varies more across classrooms within schools than it does among schools. 

We also hypothesize that (2a) sense of belonging and academic identity for Latino and African American students is more sensitive to variation in context than sense of belonging and academic identity among non-Hispanic white students. This contextual variation at the classroom level includes (2b) teacher mindsets and (2c) the proportion of their classmates who share their racial/ethnic identity. Finally, we hypothesize that (3) students will experience more growth in mathematics in classrooms where they have a greater sense of belonging.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between-subjects design, nested within classrooms and schools.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Some administrative data routinely collected by the school district already exist. We will use teacher and student demographic characteristics as control variables and school/classroom of record to locate and situate teachers and students into their educational contexts. None of these data currently allow us to discern any patterns about teacher or student mindsets. The district does collect individual-level data on student and teacher mindsets; we replicate some of those items in our surveys. We will use this replication- and the repetition of those measures over time- to explore the contribution of teacher to student belonging in a value added framework. We have not accessed these data at the time of writing.

question.value: We will invite all 11 middle schools in the school district to participate in the study. Each school's leadership can choose to participate independently of other schools' decisions. We will administer surveys and collect administrative data for all students in each school that consents to participate. Student surveys will be administered at the school during a time of the school’s choosing, via Qualtrics on a web platform. Students will not be compensated for participating in the survey. We will invite all mathematics teachers and support teacher engaged primarily in math instruction from participating schools to complete teacher surveys. Each teacher will receive a $5 unconditional incentive at recruitment and a $20 incentive after completing the survey. The survey will also be administered via Qualtrics on a web platform.  Recruitment of schools is open until January 17th, 2020. Recruitment of teachers is open until February 14th, 2020.

Outcome Variables

School belonging survey items. The social belonging items measure the degree to which students feel as if they fit in socially and academically at their school. There are eight  items in the school belonging scale as it is administered to students, each on a five-point Likert style scale. Seven items have response categories ranging from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Items are: 

I feel I belong at this school.
The adults at my school encourage me.
I enjoy going to school.
In my classes, the main role of teachers is to ensure all students learn what is covered in class.
My teachers care about how well I do in school.
I make an effort to learn even when work feels hard.
In my classes, the main role of teachers is to give the best grades only to the best students. 

One additional item is:
How well do you fit in at your school?
[not at all, a little, somewhat well, very well, extremely well] 

Classroom belonging survey items. The classroom belonging items measure the degree to which students feel as if they fit in socially and academically in a specific classroom. Items ask all students how they feel about math class and one other class that is not math class. Items for both classes are:

How much do you feel like you belong when you are in [CLASS] class?
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot,completely]
How connected do you feel to your classmates in [CLASS]? 
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot,completely]
How much does your [CLASS] teacher value and listen to your ideas?
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, quite a lot]

	Items specifically related to math class are: 

How much does your [MATH] teacher value and listen to your ideas?
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, quite a lot]
How often does your [MATH] teacher treat you with respect?
[never, rarely, sometimes, most of the time, all of the time]
How successful does your [MATH] teacher expect you to be?
[not at all successful, somewhat successful, successful, very successful, 
extremely successful]
How interested is your [MATH] teacher in hearing about your background or past experiences?
[not at all interested, a little interested, somewhat interested, very interested, extremely interested]
How much does your [MATH] teacher encourage you to share things about your family or community in the classroom”
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, quite a lot]
		
Math identity survey items. Math identity items measure the degree to which students feel as if math is something they are good at and something others associate with them. They may feel enjoyment when working through math problems or simply believe that they are capable of grasping the concepts in mathematics. Items are: 

To what extent do you see yourself as a math person?
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, quite a lot]
To what extent do others see you as a math person?
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, quite a lot]

How confident are you that you can understand the most difficult material presented by your [MATH] teacher?  
[Not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident, certain]
How confident are you that you can do an excellent job on your [MATH] assignments? 
[Not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident, certain]
How confident are you that you can master the skills being taught in your [MATH] class?

MAP math scaled scores (fall and spring). Measures of Academic Progress (MAP) math scaled scores are those reported in district administrative data. 

	Predictor Variables

Teacher school belonging survey items. The teacher social belonging items measure the degree to which teachers feel as if they fit in socially and academically at their school. There are five items in the school belonging scale as it is administered to teachers, each on a five-point Likert style scale. Items have response categories ranging from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Items are:

I feel I belong at this school.
Staff members respect each other's work
I enjoy going to work
Staff help each other when it is needed.
Staff encourage students to believe that intelligence can grow through effort.
	
Teacher relational trust survey items. Relational trust items measure the degree to which teachers believe other school personnel respect them, are trustworthy and reliable, and care about each other. Items are: 
To what extent do you feel respected by other teachers?'
[not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, completely]
How comfortable do you feel discussing feelings, worries, and frustrations with other teachers in your school?
[not at all comfortable, a little comfortable, somewhat comfortable, very comfortable, extremely comfortable]
How much do you: [not at all, a little, somewhat, a lot, completely]:
Trust other teachers in this school?
Respect other teachers in this school?
Care about other teachers in the school?
Trust your principal?
Respect your principal?
Believe in the equity vision of this school?

Teacher implicit theory of intelligence survey items. Implicit theory of intelligence items ask teachers the degree to which they believe intelligence is a fixed and permanent state of being or something that can grow and change. Items have response categories ranging from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Items are: 

To be honest, students have a certain amount of intelligence, and they really can't do much to change it.
Some people are math people and some are not.
Anyone can learn math if they put in the effort.
Your intelligence is something about you that you can't change very much.
I worry my students will become discouraged if I challenge them.

Teacher beliefs about disadvantaged learners survey items. Items have response categories ranging from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Items are: 

All students should be treated the same, regardless of their race, ethnicity, or background.
All students have the same path to success, regardless of their race, ethnicity, or background.
Being a successful student requires skills that are more common among students from advantaged groups than students from disadvantaged groups.
The disadvantaged backgrounds that some students come from are often a barrier to their success.
Students from disadvantaged groups have to overcome their backgrounds in order to succeed.
Students who are struggling would do better if their parents cared more about school.
Because of their past experiences, students from disadvantaged backgrounds have unique strengths that can help them succeed.
The backgrounds that students from disadvantaged groups come from will help them be successful.
Students who are struggling would do better if they cared more about school.

Teacher self-efficacy survey items. Self-efficacy items measure the degree to which teachers believe they can help students succeed. Items are: 

How confident are you that you can:

help the least prepared students in  your [CLASS] class succeed in math?
[not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident, extremely confident]
directly impact students’ achievement in mathematics through what you do in the [CLASS] class?
[not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident, extremely confident]
get students in [CLASS] interested in  mathematics?
[not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident, extremely confident]
explain mathematical concepts to students in [CLASS] who have difficulty understanding math?
[not at all confident, a little confident, somewhat confident, very confident,
extremely confident]

	Covariates

Student gender. A measure differentiating male, female and gender non-binary students

Student race. A categorical variable differentiating white, black or African American, Hispanic or Latino,Asian, and Other race or ethnicity students

Parental education. A categorical variable differentiating students whose parents’ highest education is less than high school, a high school diploma, some college, a bachelor’s degree, or an advanced degree.

Free/reduced-priced lunch participation. A binary variable differentiating students who participate in free or reduced-priced lunch and those who do not.

ELL status. A binary measure differentiating students who are English language learners and those who are not.

IEP status. A binary measure differentiating students who have an individualized education plan and those who do not. 

Prior disciplinary referrals. A count of the number of office disciplinary referrals reported for each student in official district records prior to the date of the survey administration.

Student GPA (prior year)

Student math grades (prior year)

Student MAP math test score (prior year)

The survey items listed above (i.e., student school belonging, classroom belonging, math identity; teacher school belonging, relational trust, implicit theory of intelligence, self-efficacy, beliefs about disadvantaged learners) are part of a new survey and when compiled comprise several scale measures. We discuss construction of these scales further in the Analysis Plan.

Scale construction

We anticipate combining the items from each survey into their respective scales as detailed above. To determine the final scales for analyses, we will begin by calculating Cronbach’s alpha to determine the internal consistency of each scale. We will perform confirmatory factor analyses (CFA) and refinine each scale based on fit indices as necessary. We will use several heuristics to assess goodness of fit for each scale. We will consider an alpha of 0.60 or higher as acceptable internal consistency. We will consider a Comparative Fit Index of 0.90 or higher as the threshold for acceptable fit of a scale in CFA analyses.   

Statistical models

Distribution of belonging in and between schools

Our modeling strategy will conform closely to that of Farrington, Porter and Klugmnan (2019). We will first assess uniformity of scale measurement for student measures of school and classroom belonging across race/ethnicity, sex, parental education and family income (measured by whether or not students have ever participated in the free or reduced lunch programs). We will also evaluate the correlation between the school-level belonging measures previously employed by MMSD and our measures. The greater the correlation in these sets of items, the more confidence we can have in drawing on additional years of MMSD data to estimate models of variation in students belonging within and between schools (but not by classroom). 

Next, we will estimate a series of random-effects models to explore how students’ sense of belonging varies at the classroom, student and school levels. Let Yics be a measure of belonging or academic identity for student i in class c in school s. We will first estimate a model to decompose the variance in student belonging and academic identity: 

𝑌𝑖𝑐𝑠=𝛾000+𝑢0𝑐𝑠+𝑟00𝑠+𝑒𝑖𝑐𝑠 (1) 

Where 0cs is a class*school specific random effect, r00s is a school-specific random effect and eics is a student-specific random effect. Assuming these sources of variance are independent, this basic equation will reflect how sense of belonging and academic identity varies among students, between classes and between schools. 

Next, we will consider how student attributes Z, including race/ethnicity, gender, parental education and student FRPL status, prior disciplinary referrals and prior academic performance (measured by grades and test scores) are associated with student sense of belonging and academic identity. Finally, we will distinguish between math and social studies courses by including a dummy indicator for math (mathis). This specification will allow us to a) understand variation in belonging across types of courses and b) support the inclusion of interaction terms to see if differences in belonging across subjects varies by student attributes including race/ethnicity, gender and parental education and income. The main effects version of this model (without interactions) is:

𝑌𝑖𝑐𝑠=𝛾000+𝒁𝜷+𝑚𝑎𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑠𝛿𝑠+𝑟00𝑠+𝑒𝑖𝑐𝑠 (2)

We will also evaluate, for only math classes, variation in math identity. In that case we will omit the math class indicator.

Teacher mindset and belonging

We will begin our analyses by estimating confirmatory factor models to evaluate the quality of our teacher mindset and belonging scales and to explore whether the measurement properties of these scales vary across school contexts defined by the racial/ethnic and socioeconomic composition of the school. Next, we will evaluate how if at all teacher mindset is related to students’ feelings of belonging, academic (math) identity and achievement growth. To explore the contribution of teacher beliefs to student belonging, we will modify eq (2) to reflect the contribution of teacher mindset at the classroom and school levels, school mean centering measures of teacher mindset and estimating parameters for the contribution of individual and school average measures of teacher mindset to student belonging.

We will pursue a similar strategy to analyze the contribution of teacher mindset to student math identity and academic growth. Importantly, MMSD assesses all middle school students in mathematics with the Measures of Academic Progress in both fall and spring, supporting analyses of growth over the academic rather than calendar year.

Practices, behaviors and instructional environments associated with belonging

We will follow these observations with one-on-one semi-structured interviews with teachers to learn about their instructional philosophy, pedagogical decision-making process and how if at all they perceive the relationship between their mindset and sense of belonging and their students’ educational experiences. We will also interview a sample of students in each classroom to learn how they experience and respond to their teachers.

We will recruit teachers based on a modified version of equation (1) in which we condition only on student background attributes, including prior year GPA: 𝑌𝑖𝑐𝑠=𝛾000+𝒁𝜷+𝑢0𝑐𝑠+𝑟00𝑠+𝑒𝑖𝑐𝑠 We will then draw a sample of math classrooms stratified based on the classroom random effects (0cs) such that we sample a total of 20 classrooms—7 each from the top and bottom quartiles of value-added for student belonging and 3 each from the middle two quartiles. If we are unsuccessful in recruiting particular classrooms, we will replace them with another classroom form the same quartile.

registration_responses.q1: What Makes a Classroom a Community? Teacher Mindsets and Student Sense of Belonging in Middle School Math Classes
registration_responses.q3:
We propose to build on insights rooted in contemporary psychology to understand how the mindsets and practices of teachers influence students’ sense of belonging and academic identity in middle school in general and in middle school mathematics classes in particular. Despite a wealth of literature on the subject of belonging, it remains unclear how much student sense of belonging varies across organizational contexts, including schools and classrooms, nor the extent to which teacher behaviors and beliefs contribute to students’ sense of belonging. We ask the following research questions:

How is student sense of belonging distributed within and between middle schools? 

How is teacher mindset related to student sense of belonging, academic identity and student success in middle school in general and mathematics classes in particular? How if at all does the relationship vary by student race and ethnicity? 

What sorts of practices, behaviors and instructional environments are associated with stronger student sense of belonging and math identity for middle school students in general and students of color in particular?
registration_responses.q4:
We hypothesize that organizational contexts, teacher beliefs and teacher practices shape students’ sense of belonging and academic identity in ways that differ among students from different racial and ethnic groups. In general we expect to find that (1) student sense of belonging and academic identity varies more across classrooms within schools than it does among schools. 

We also hypothesize that (2a) sense of belonging and academic identity for Latino and African American students is more sensitive to variation in context than sense of belonging and academic identity among non-Hispanic white students. This contextual variation at the classroom level includes (2b) teacher mindsets and (2c) the proportion of their classmates who share their racial/ethnic identity. Finally, we hypothesize that (3) students will experience more growth in mathematics in classrooms where they have a greater sense of belonging.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Some administrative data routinely collected by the school district already exist. We will use teacher and student demographic characteristics as control variables and school/classroom of record to locate and situate teachers and students into their educational contexts. None of these data currently allow us to discern any patterns about teacher or student mindsets. The district does collect individual-level data on student and teacher mindsets; we replicate some of those items in our surveys. We will use this replication- and the repetition of those measures over time- to explore the contribution of teacher to student belonging in a value added framework. We have not accessed these data at the time of writing.

attributes.title: Learning About Ancient Rome (Performance Anticipation)
attributes.description: In this study, we will examine the effect of performance anticipation on memory of details presented in a lecture video.

q1.value: Examining the effect of performance anticipation on lecture comprehension

q3.value:
Our past research has demonstrated that when participants believe they will have to give a brief research presentation to other participants in a classroom setting, their memory for a confederate's research presentation is significantly poorer than those who believe they will not have to give a presentation. In addition, at the end of the study, the participants who believed they were going to have to present retrospectively reported having experienced significantly higher ratings of anxiety and thoughts related to their own presentation than those who believed they would not be presenting. 

In the current study, we seek to extend these findings by investigating whether performance anticipation reduces students' learning and memory for a lecture that precedes their upcoming presentations.  Thus, we seek to expand the generalizability of the results from our previous study with the current study.  

In addition, we seek to better understand the subjective experience of performance anticipation via the inclusion of self-report measures that will be included at three time points throughout the video lecture (toward the beginning, middle, and end of the video).  In particular, we will assess whether anxiety and attention mediates the relation between our performance anticipation manipulation and memory for lecture content.

q4.value:
Multiple-choice performance:

We predict that participants who expect to give a presentation on a research article following a video lecture about ancient Rome will demonstrate significantly worse memory for the lecture (i.e., lower MC quiz scores on average) than participants who believe they will not have to give a presentation, replicating the general findings of our first study.

Self-report ratings during the lecture:

In terms of the self-report ratings during the video lecture, we predict that participants who believe they will have to give a presentation may demonstrate the following (in comparison to people who don't believe they have to give a presentation):

- Decreased attentiveness while watching the video.  (main measure of interest)
- Increased feelings of anxiety while watching the video.  (main measure of interest)
-Decreased feelings of motivation while watching the video.  (exploratory measure)

- We do not have specific predictions regarding the effort and boredom measures.  We have included them to decrease the probability that participants will correctly infer our hypothesis.

In addition, we predict that, for participants who expect to give a presentation after the lecture, they will become increasingly less attentive, more anxious, and less motivated as the lecture progresses (relative to participants who do not expect to give a presentation), leading to significant Condition x Time interactions for these measures.

Mediation models:

We predict that  both attentiveness and anxiety will mediate the relation between our performance anticipation manipulation (i.e., presenting vs. not presentation) and multiple-choice score.

Retrospective self-report measures:

We predict that participants who had expected to give an oral presentation will retrospectively rate themselves as having mind-wandered more often during the lecture and as having been more anxious during the lecture relative to participants who had not expected to give an oral presentation.  Moreover, we predict that participants who had expected to give an oral presentation will tend to indicate that their mind-wandering was about their upcoming presentation.

Participants who expected to present will rate how much they specifically thought about their upcoming performance on a scale from 0 to 10.  We predict that this measure will be significantly negatively correlated with memory for lecture content.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants will be undergraduate students enrolled in a psychology course who are participating in research in exchange for course credit.

We will run participants in groups of 6-20 (depending on how many sign-ups we are able to obtain for a given experimental session).

This is a between-subjects design consisting of two groups (presenting - i.e., high performance anticipation, or non-presenting - i.e., low performance anticipation).

First, the experimenter will assign participants a brief psychology article to study.  Participants will be asked to write down 10 specific details from the study (see the "Summarizing a Research Article" document below).  Participants will further be informed that they may have to give a brief oral presentation in front of the experimenter and other participants regarding those details.  

After 20 minutes, the experimenter will collect the "Summarizing a Research Article document" and participants will be informed that the next task involves watching a video lecture on Roman history.  Prior to the lecture video starting, participants will be informed whether they will be (a) giving a presentation on their research article after the lecture (high performance anticipation condition), or (b) merely observing other participants' presentations (low performance anticipation condition).

During the lecture video, the lecture will pause three times (toward the beginning, middle, and end of the video), and participants will answer the self-report questions (see the "Lecture Experience Questions - Presenting" and the "Lecture Experience Questions - Not Presenting" documents).

Immediately after the lecture, all participants will be informed that no one will be giving a presentation on their research article due to time constraints and that the next part of the study will be a quiz regarding the content of the lecture.  After participants write the quiz, there will be a post-lecture survey that will assess participants' mind-wandering and anxiety during the lecture.

Note that the file "Performance Anticipation Study 2 Questionnaire" is old and was replaced with "Lecture Experience Questions" documents.  (There does not seem to be a way to delete uploaded files.)  All of the final files used in the experiment will be uploaded to OSF.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to conditions based on where they are seated in the room (i.e., the experimenter will hand out the "Lecture Experience Questions" sheets such that the presenting and not presenting conditions alternate.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants are undergraduate students recruited through a participant pool at the University of Waterloo. There are no exclusion criteria. The participants are rewarded 1.5 credits for their participation, and the study takes approximately 1.5 hour to complete.

q13.value: We will be collecting data from 100 participants per condition. Since we are running two conditions, we will require 200 participants in total.

q14.value: Our primary hypothesis involves testing a main effect across two experimental conditions (participant’s perception of presenting or not presenting). Assuming a small-medium effect size of 0.4 and a statistical power of 0.80, the minimum sample size per group (for a two-tailed hypothesis) would be 100.

q15.value:
We will run the study until we have 80 usable data files for each condition. This means that if we run participants but for some reason cannot use their data later (e.g., a deviation in procedure occurred), we will exclude that participant and continue collecting for that condition as if that participant had not been run (we will however, report the exclusion of those participants our manuscript).

Since we are running large groups of participants, it is likely that we will end up with more than 100 participants per condition.  We will gladly take the extra statistical power if that happens.  Thus, we expect to end up with between 100-115 participants in each condition.

question.value: We plan to manipulate performance anticipation via the instructions that participants get (i.e., "you and a few other participants will take turns giving a 2-3 minute oral presentation on the research article that you read" or "a few other participants will take turns giving a 2-3 minute oral presentation on the research article that you read.  You will not be giving a presentation".

After viewing the video lecture, participants will complete a memory test regarding the content of the video lecture. Memory performance from this multiple-choice test is our main outcome measure. 

Online (i.e., during the video lecture) self-report measures that we will use are:
1) Attentiveness
2) Anxiety
3) Motivation 

Retrospective measures (after the lecture and quiz) that we will use are:

1) Participants will be asked what they mind-wandered about during the lecture.  We will code this measure in terms of whether the mind-wandering had to do with the research article that they read earlier or not.

2) Participants will rate the extent to which their thoughts drifted during the lecture

3) Participants will rate their anxiety during the lecture.

4) Participants who expected to present will rate how much they specifically thought about their upcoming performance on a scale from 0 to 10.

Multilevel modelling will be used to test all of our hypothesis.  Given that we will have participants completing the study in simulated classes with groups up to 20 participants, the experiences of each group may have shared variance, providing us with the rational to test this question with a multilevel model. 

A mediation analysis will be conducted to determine whether attentiveness and anxiety mediate the relationship between performance anticipation and memory performance. In step 1, we will determine the extent to which performance anticipation predicts performance on the multiple-choice test. In step 2, we will examine the extent to which performance anticipation predicts each of our mediators. Finally, in step 3 we will examine the extent to which performance anticipation and individuals’ levels of anxiety predict performance on the multiple-choice test. This process/mediation model will be run for each of the predictor variables separately.

q22.value:
Participants who are noncompliant by failing to answer any of the online (during lecture) self-report measures for attentiveness, anxiety, or motivation will be excluded.  Participants who do not answer a single multiple-choice question will be excluded.

Since the retrospective questions on the post-lecture survey are of secondary interest, we will not exclude participants who fail to answer one or more of those questions.

q23.value:
Please see the exclusion criteria above.

For the multiple-choice questions, questions that are not answered will be marked as incorrect.  On the post-lecture survey, missing data will simply be left blank/missing.

q24.value: We will explore whether there is a relation between the number of details of the article that were written down on the "Summarizing a Research Article" sheet and memory for lecture content.  This is especially of interest for participants who expected to give a presentation.

attributes.title: Prevention Interventions to address Opioid Misuse in Adolescents and Young Adults: A Systematic Review

summary.value:
Most opioid misuse begins during adolescence and young adulthood.
Therefore, adolescence and young adulthood are the time to intervene with
prevention interventions. This systematic review sets out to gather
information on key characteristics and delivery methods of currently available
effective interventions. The synthesis of this information can be used to
inform novel prevention interventions for opioid misuse.

Our research questions are: 
What are the key characteristics of effective interventions targeting opioid
misuse prevention in adolescents?
What are the key elements of effective delivery approaches of interventions
targeting opioid misuse prevention in adolescents?

q1.value: Merit & Privilege: Advantage vs. Disadvantage Framing

q2.value: Stephanie Tepper, Rachel King, Amy Krosch

q3.value: Our research thus far finds that acknowledging the role of privilege in an accomplishment threatens perceptions of merit or deservingness. In this study, we seek to test whether reframing White privilege as a lack of disadvantage based on race (vs. as an advantage based on race) might make it easier for people to acknowledge the role of privilege in their accomplishments.

q4.value: Our central hypothesis is that participants who see privilege framed as a lack of disadvantage will be more likely to acknowledge their privilege. We also hypothesize that these participants' ratings of the role of merit will be the same as those who see privilege framed as an advantage; this is because we expect that the disadvantage framing will make privilege seem like less of a threat to merit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study employs a three-group, between-subjects design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three between-subjects conditions using the Qualtrics block randomization feature.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolific Academic. We will compensate participants $0.48 for their participation in this 3-minute survey (a rate of $9.60/hour). We will restrict our sample to White participants living in the United States.

q13.value: We will collect responses from 450 participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using G*Power. A sample size of 450 participants will enable us to detect a small-to-medium Cohen's f of .17 at 90% power.

q15.value: Aside from occasional errors with online data collection (in which more or fewer people participate than requested), we will have full control over our sample size.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions. 

1. In the control condition, participants will simply rate the role that privilege played in their accomplishment with a simple definition of privilege ("advantages based on your race"). 
2. In the advantage condition, participants will read the following before rating the role of privilege in their accomplishment: "Having racial privilege means that your race puts you at an advantage in society compared to members of other racial groups. In other words, your racial identity has cleared a path for your successes in life and has made it easier for you to achieve your goals."
3. In the disadvantage condition, participants will read the following before rating the role of privilege in their accomplishment: "Having racial privilege means that your race does not put you at a disadvantage in society compared to members of other racial groups. In other words, your racial identity has not been a barrier on the path to your successes in life and has not made it more difficult for you to achieve your goals."

Participants will write about an accomplishment in their lives. Participants will then rate the role of privilege (with the accompanying manipulation in each condition). Participants will rate the role of merit in their accomplishments as well. Finally, participants will rate the extent to which they believe that acknowledging their privilege threatens their merit. See attached for the full survey.
N/A

1. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of privilege between conditions. 
2. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of merit between conditions. 
3. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of the extent to which acknowledging privilege threatens merit between conditions.

q21.value: We will use a standard alpha of .05 to make inferences.

q22.value: If participants indicate that they will not provide quality responses, or if they indicate that they have taken a similar survey on Amazon Mechanical Turk, we will exclude their data from the analyses.

q23.value: If any items for measures that will be included in the analyses are missing, the corresponding cases will be removed from the analyses.

q1.value: Group vs. Individual Inequality: Oxfam Report

q3.value: Our previous studies find that people judge unequal situations to be more fair when there is an individual at the "top" of the distribution rather than a group, even though this type of "individual" inequality might reflect a more unequal distribution of resources. In this study, we compare the wealth of the top 26 richest people in the world vs. the wealth of the richest person in the world, stating that the amount held by these people/this person is equal to the combined wealth of the 3.8 billion vs. 146 million poorest people in the world. In the "group" inequality condition, we will also explain that if the wealth of the 26 richest people is equal to the wealth of the 3.8 billion poorest people, this means that the wealth of each of the richest people is equal to the wealth of 146 million of the poorest people (to equate the numbers in both conditions). We will ask participants to judge the fairness of this distribution of wealth and explore some possible mechanisms and downstream consequences of this judgment.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that:

1. Participants will judge the inequality in the group condition (26 richest people) to be less fair than the inequality in the individual condition (richest person).
2. Participants will judge the world's richest person to be more deserving of their wealth than the world's 26 richest people.
3. Participants will attribute the wealth of the world's richest person to more internal (vs. external) factors, compared to the wealth of the world's 26 richest people.
4. After learning about the wealth of the world's 26 richest people (vs. the world's richest person), participants will be more supportive of redistributive policies.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study employs a two-group, between-subjects design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk. We will compensate participants $0.64 for their participation in this 4-minute survey (a rate of $9.60/hour).

q13.value: We will collect responses from 400 participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using G*Power. A sample size of 400 participants will enable us to detect a Cohen's d of .36 (from previous studies) at 95% power.

q15.value: Aside from occasional errors with data collection through Mechanical Turk (in which more or fewer people participate than requested), we will have full control over our sample size.

question.value: Participants will be assigned to one of two conditions: group-based inequality (wealth of 26 richest people = wealth of 3.8 billion poorest people, or or approximately 146 million of the poorest people for each of the 26 richest people) and individual-based inequality (wealth of richest person = wealth of 146 million poorest people).

Our main dependent variable will be participants' judgments of fairness and deservingness: 
1. The inequality reflected in statistics like these is... (scale from 1, not at all fair, to 9, extremely fair)
2. How deserving of their wealth [are the world's 26 richest people/is the world's richest person]? (scale from 1, not at all deserving, to 9, entirely deserving)

We will also measure internal vs. external attributions as a possible mechanism: 
3. Would you say that the success of [these 26 people vs. this person] is due more to societal attributes like an economic system that has favored them?  Or would you say that their success is due more to personal attributes like being extremely talented? (scale from 1, Their success is due entirely to societal attributes, to 9, Their success is due entirely to personal attributes)

Finally, we will describe an inheritance tax (as an example of a redistributive policy) and measure support for this policy using three items:
4. Rate the extent to which you agree that an inheritance tax should be implemented in your state.
5. How much do you support or oppose the implementation of an inheritance tax in your state?
6. How likely would you be to vote in favor of an inheritance tax if it appeared on your state's election ballot?
The three items for the policy support measure will be averaged into a single composite measure of overall policy support.

We will conduct t-tests to assess differences between conditions on:
1. The fairness measure
2. The deservingness measure
3. The internal vs. external attribution measure
4. The policy support measure

registration_responses.q1: Group vs. Individual Inequality: Oxfam Report
registration_responses.q3: Our previous studies find that people judge unequal situations to be more fair when there is an individual at the "top" of the distribution rather than a group, even though this type of "individual" inequality might reflect a more unequal distribution of resources. In this study, we compare the wealth of the top 26 richest people in the world vs. the wealth of the richest person in the world, stating that the amount held by these people/this person is equal to the combined wealth of the 3.8 billion vs. 146 million poorest people in the world. In the "group" inequality condition, we will also explain that if the wealth of the 26 richest people is equal to the wealth of the 3.8 billion poorest people, this means that the wealth of each of the richest people is equal to the wealth of 146 million of the poorest people (to equate the numbers in both conditions). We will ask participants to judge the fairness of this distribution of wealth and explore some possible mechanisms and downstream consequences of this judgment.
registration_responses.q4:
We hypothesize that:

1. Participants will judge the inequality in the group condition (26 richest people) to be less fair than the inequality in the individual condition (richest person).
2. Participants will judge the world's richest person to be more deserving of their wealth than the world's 26 richest people.
3. Participants will attribute the wealth of the world's richest person to more internal (vs. external) factors, compared to the wealth of the world's 26 richest people.
4. After learning about the wealth of the world's 26 richest people (vs. the world's richest person), participants will be more supportive of redistributive policies.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomized to one of two between-subjects conditions using the Qualtrics block randomization feature.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will collect responses from 400 participants.
registration_responses.q14: We conducted a power analysis using G*Power. A sample size of 400 participants will enable us to detect a Cohen's d of .36 (from previous studies) at 95% power.
registration_responses.q15: Aside from occasional errors with data collection through Mechanical Turk (in which more or fewer people participate than requested), we will have full control over our sample size.
registration_responses.q21: We will use a standard alpha of .05 to make inferences.
registration_responses.q23: If any items for measures that will be included in the analyses are missing, the corresponding cases will be removed from the analyses.
registration_responses.q8.question: This study employs a two-group, between-subjects design.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk. We will compensate participants $0.64 for their participation in this 4-minute survey (a rate of $9.60/hour).
registration_responses.q16.question: Participants will be assigned to one of two conditions: group-based inequality (wealth of 26 richest people = wealth of 3.8 billion poorest people, or or approximately 146 million of the poorest people for each of the 26 richest people) and individual-based inequality (wealth of richest person = wealth of 146 million poorest people).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Our main dependent variable will be participants' judgments of fairness and deservingness: 
1. The inequality reflected in statistics like these is... (scale from 1, not at all fair, to 9, extremely fair)
2. How deserving of their wealth [are the world's 26 richest people/is the world's richest person]? (scale from 1, not at all deserving, to 9, entirely deserving)

We will also measure internal vs. external attributions as a possible mechanism: 
3. Would you say that the success of [these 26 people vs. this person] is due more to societal attributes like an economic system that has favored them?  Or would you say that their success is due more to personal attributes like being extremely talented? (scale from 1, Their success is due entirely to societal attributes, to 9, Their success is due entirely to personal attributes)

Finally, we will describe an inheritance tax (as an example of a redistributive policy) and measure support for this policy using three items:
4. Rate the extent to which you agree that an inheritance tax should be implemented in your state.
5. How much do you support or oppose the implementation of an inheritance tax in your state?
6. How likely would you be to vote in favor of an inheritance tax if it appeared on your state's election ballot?
registration_responses.q18.question: The three items for the policy support measure will be averaged into a single composite measure of overall policy support.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will conduct t-tests to assess differences between conditions on:
1. The fairness measure
2. The deservingness measure
3. The internal vs. external attribution measure
4. The policy support measure

attributes.title: The gene-culture coevolution of group identities: the role of similarity in social-learning
attributes.description: People tend to coordinate their actions with those from the same cultural group. Signals of cultural group membership can be hidden or subtle, however. This is the first study to investigate how the reliability of our similarity-information to others affects whether we use a social-learning strategy to learn from said others. This study investigates social-learning on both an asocial (best-choice) and social (coordination game) task. Please see the pre-register word document under files for full study information and appendices.

attributes.title: Hedonic Distraction
attributes.description: A series of studies exploring if emotionally charged distraction helps or hinders self-regulation

q1.value: Hedonic Distraction Choice - Positive vs. Neutral

q3.value: The purpose of the current study is to compare self-regulation strategy choice between positive distraction and neutral distraction in the context of the regulation of desire for calorie-dense snacks. This is the second in a set of studies (first ongoing and un-analysed) exploring the roles of hedonic forms of distraction during self-regulation. The primary purpose of this project is to test if participants preferentially choose to engage in distraction using positively valenced imagery over neutral imagery a) overall, and b) particularly in the context of highly craved foods.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: If positive distraction is self-reinforcing, participants should choose to engage in positive distraction on a majority of trials (i.e., more than 50%) relative to neutral distraction

Hypothesis 2: If participants prefer positive distraction particularly for highly craved foods, then they should choose positive distraction over neutral distraction with increasing frequency as pre-rated cravings for individual foods increases. 

A secondary hypothesis will be to test the relative effectiveness of positive vs. negative distraction, however, a simultaneous separate study without the choice component (preregistration - Hedonic Distraction - Study 1) provides a stronger test of this hypothesis.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will use a fully within-subjects, repeated measures design. Each participant will take part in two conditions that ask them to use different types of regulation: positive distraction and neutral distraction. The experiment will consist of 60 trials and participants will make a forced choice between using positive distraction and neutral distraction on each trial.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the University of Dundee area through an advertisement on our participant recruitment system (SONA) and posters. Participants will be undergraduate students who will receive three course credits in an undergraduate (year 1 and year 2) Psychology course for taking part. Participants will attend the lab in-person to take part in the study.

Participants must be at least 18 years of age, and we will ask participants to fast for a minimum of 6 hours prior to participation.

q13.value: We will collect data from 54 participants and then stop data collection. Each participant will make 60 choices (i.e., 60 trials) and each data-point will be entered into the analyses. Thus, there will be 54 participants at level 2, and 3240 trials at level 1.

Hypothesis 1 (see code in Analysis Plan):

Hypothesis 2 (see code in Analysis Plan), simR apriori power analysis output:

Based on 1000 simulations

q15.value: Data termination will end when we have at least 54 participants. Because participants are ran in pairs, it is possible that we will slightly over-shoot this target. However, no data-analyses will be conducted on interim data.

question.value: The only manipulated variable in the study will be the within-subjects condition of strategy choice. This condition will have levels. Positive distraction (think of a happy thought) and neutral distraction (think of a neutral thought). Participants will select which strategy to enact on each trial of the experiment (60 trials total).

1) choice - binary decision between positive distraction and neutral distraction
2) pre-choice craving levels (1-9, 9 = highest craving level). 
3) Post-implementation desire (1-9, 9 = highest desire).
4) cash bid as a behavioural measure of the food value (0-2 GBP in 9 equal intervals).

Hypothesis 1: Overall bias towards positive distraction (one-sample t-test on DV % overall choosing distraction):

Bias.PositiveDistraction = t.test(Percent.PostitiveDistraction, mu=50)


Hypothesis 2: Craving intensity predicting strategy choice (multilevel logistic regression with craving level predicting strategy choice):

modelCraving = glmer(Choice ~ Craving_rating + (1 + Craving_rating |ParticipantID), family = binomial(link=logit), data = data) 


Supplementary test of effectiveness will first be conducted on a differences score (post-implementation desire - pre-implementation craving) and on the cash bids made by participants to buy the foods. 

Craving <- lmer(DifferenceScore ~ Choice + (1+ Choice|ParticipantID),data=data)

We will conduct a further test of this hypothesis using the identical model, but restricting to only cases where pre-rated craving was maximal (i.e., 9/9)

q21.value: We will use conventional alpha of .05, but will interpret p-values continuously (i.e., ps less than .005 will be interpreted as strong evidence, while ps greater than .005 and less than  .05 will be interpreted as suggestive).

q22.value:
Absolute deviation around the median will be used to identify and exclude outliers on each DV (i.e., bids and desires). 

Leys, C., Ley, C., Klein, O., Bernard, P., Licata, L., 2013. Detecting outliers: Do not use
standard deviation around the mean, use absolute deviation around the median. J.
Exp. Soc. Psychol. 49(4), 764-766. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2013.03.013

q23.value: Missing data will be allowed for by using the MLM approach. Participants will be retained even if they have missing data.
